Moreover, this factorization is unique up to isomorphism in the sense that if A \twoheadrightarrow C \rightarrowtail B and A \twoheadrightarrow C' \rightarrowtail B are both cover-mono factorizations of the same morphism, then C \cong C'.

An epimorphism f \colon A \twoheadrightarrow B is said to be extremal (also called a cover) if for any monomorphism m \colon C \rightarrowtail B and any morphism g \colon A \to C such that f = mg, then m is an isomorphism.

A category \mathcal { C } is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } be a regular functor and f \colon A \to B be a morphism in \mathcal { C }. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F( \mathsf { Img } (f))F( \vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf { Img } (Ff) \cong F( \mathsf { Img } (f)).

A category \mathcal { C } is said to have images if the inclusion functor \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} admits a left adjoint \mathsf { Img } \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to \mathsf { Sub } (A) for all objects A \in \mathcal { C }.
A category \mathcal { C } is locally cartesian iff it has pullbacks.

If \mathcal { C } is locally cartesian, then { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} has products for any object A \in \mathcal { C }. But, products in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} are pullbacks over A. Thus, \mathcal { C } has pullbacks.

Conversely, assume that \mathcal { C } has pullbacks. Then since the forgetful functor \Sigma _{A} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to \mathcal { C } creates connected limits for any object A \in \mathcal { C }, the slice { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} has pullbacks. Moreover, \mathsf {id} _{ A } is the terminal object in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}}. Thus, { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} is cartesian.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a cartesian category equipped with a subobject classifier. Every monomorphism in \mathcal { C } is regular.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Separated objects correspond to closed diagonal relations

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An object A of a topos \mathcal { E } is separated iff the diagonal subobject \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A is closed.
A (Lawvere-Tierney) topology on a topos \mathcal { E } is a morphism j \colon \Omega \to \Omega satisfying the following equations.
Let j be a topology on a topos. A subobject m \colon A \rightarrowtail B is said to be j-closed if its closure is isomorphic to itself.
Let j be a topology on a topos. Let m \colon A \rightarrowtail B be a subobject. The j-closure of m is the subobject classified by j \chi _{m} \colon B \to \Omega.
Let j be a topology on a topos. A subobject m \colon A \rightarrowtail B is said to be j-dense if its closure is an isomorphism.
An equivalence relation is said to be effective if it is the kernel pair of some morphism.
Let (a,b) \colon R \rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a category with finite limits. (a,b) is said to be an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every equivalence relation in a topos is effective

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (a,b) \colon R \rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a category with finite limits. (a,b) is said to be reflexive if the diagonal relation \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A factors through (a,b), i.e., there is a map \rho \colon A \to R such that a \rho = b \rho = \mathsf {id} _{ A }.

Let j be a topology on a topos \mathcal { E }. An object S \in \mathcal { E } is said to be j-separated if for any dense subobject m \colon A \rightarrowtail B and any morphism f \colon A \to S, there is at most one morphism g \colon B \to S such that f = gm.

Let j be a topology on a topos \mathcal { E }. An object S \in \mathcal { E } is said to be a j-sheaf if for any dense subobject m \colon A \rightarrowtail B and any morphism f \colon A \to S, there is exactly one morphism g \colon B \to S such that f = gm.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobjects of separated objects are separated

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a separated object in a topos \mathcal { E }. Any subobject m \colon A' \rightarrowtail A is separated.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let m' \colon B' \rightarrowtail B be a dense subobject and f \colon B' \to A' be any morphism. If f = gm' = hm' then mf = mgm' = mhm'. First, mg = mh because A is separated. Then it follows that g = h because m is a monomorphism.
